Topic.Title: Common Sense - Why hire Evercore if Dell is not selling?

Message.Msg: Of course Michael Dell and Silverlake are trying to buy Dell. But that does not mean it is going to happen. The issue is at what price. The BOD has to hire a firm to find other potential offers and #$%$ what is a fair price. There are going to be lawsuits over this whole process. Michael Dell cannot be buyer and in charge of selling at the same time. It is a blantant conflict of interest. The people most likely to file a lawsuit are not on yahoo, but they are out there.

Topic.Title: Dell Said to Hire Evercore to Seek Higher Bids After Buyout

Message.Msg: on the one hand the acquisition group, including Michael Dell, wants the lowest price possible' on the other hand the board, including Michael Dell have a duty and an interest in securing the highest price posible. This could be either just an attempt to show best efforts were made to maximize sell price or it could be a legitimate attempt to boost sale price. Hard to say which way this will go, but my money is on $19. There has to be a significant premium to current price...

Topic.Title: Dell Said to Hire Evercore to Seek Higher Bids After Buyout

Message.Msg: They just want to make sure big investors like Southeastern Asset Management are O.K. with the selling price. With all the big boys' blessings, the deal can go through without lawsuits. Closing the deal at this point is vitally important. If the deal is done, most people benefit, if it's not done and the share price drops to $10, nobody benefits and lawsuits will ensue. This deal is as good as done in my humble opinion.

Message.Title: Pathetic Southeastern
Message.Msg: Few things in investing are as pathetic as an investor who can't deal with the reality of their losses. First, Southeastern has absolutely no legal basis to sue Dell. Zero. What Dell is attempting to do is legal. Period. When you buy shares in a company, there are always risks that you will lose some or all of your money due to a variety of reasons. Hiring Evercore was the right thing to do. Unless they can prove that Evercore didn't really try to find other deals ( good luck with that! heheheh ), they have no case. Second, if Southeastern wants to a) waste tens of millions on legal fees, and b) publicize to the world how RIDICULOUS and WRONG their investment thesis on Dell has been, then they are dumber than a bag of rocks. I have read the quotes. They are laughable. How embarrassing for Southeastern. They should keep quiet, take their loss just like the rest of us have to do when it happens, and move on. The only thing legal action against Dell will accomplish is putting money into the pockets of various law firms. And maybe options sellers (in case there is a delay due to litigation). Same goes for the bondholders. Investors can gripe and whine all they want - there is nothing even remotely illegal about what they are doing. It'll go to a shareholder vote, and the shareholders will get their legal right to vote. One vote for one share.

Message.Title: Why are Silverfish and Northeastern gumming up deal?
Message.Msg: LBO's according to Barron's always go for at least at a 25 PE of the firm being bought out. According to my calculations that puts the buyout at least $22 per share. Don't let these outfits (cockroaches) and MD steal your company. A fair price is at a 25 PE or better.

Topic.Title: Is Anyone Making Money WIth DELL?

Message.Msg: Dell Inc. (DELL), which has been in buyout talks with Silver Lake Partners , has hired Evercore Partners Inc. (EVR) to advise Dell on the possibility of a higher offer, Bloomberg News reported Monday, citing two people with knowledge of the matter. If a Silver Lake deal is formalized, Evercore would run a go-shop process to search for potentially superior offers, Bloomberg reported. Silver Lake and Michael Dell have been seeking financing for a deal that could be worth about $23 billion .

Topic.Title: Common Sense - Why hire Evercore if Dell is not selling?

Message.Msg: I agree, totally. If you sell your house, it can take months to get a decent offer; it will take several months to get a reasonable offer on a 20 billion dollar company. Evercore was hired to fulfill the appearance of due diligence. This is going to get messy. Very messy.

Topic.Title: Common Sense - Why hire Evercore if Dell is not selling?

Message.Msg: True, but not at this level. Shareholders have rights and the CEO/BOD have fiduciary responsibilities. This is not a case of some existing managers willing to go along for the ride; this is a case of the CEO orchestrating the buyout for himself and his partners what might be against the shareholders. Not good. We'll see. But it is too early to say. We have to see what the offer is and how it is presented.

Topic.Title: Common Sense - Why hire Evercore if Dell is not selling?

Message.Msg: Aside from the accounting scandal of several years back, Dell management has been doing an excellent job running the company. The same is true for other large cap older tech firms such as Microsoft, Intel, and Cisco systems. What these companies have in common is excellent business operations , good consistent profitability, large cash reserves, and for the past ten years, well below average stock price performance. Wall Street is not interested in single digit growth tech firms. Wall St. bids up the 20% plus revenues growers, or stories with potential of dramatic revenue growth. Michale dell has been more than patient with Wall St. He now has the right to take the company private. Certainly some greedy , unethical lawyers will get involved and try to milk some billings off this situation, coercing shareowners to join class action suits. Hopefully judges will throw the nusiance suits out of court and teach the #$%$ lawyers a lesson.
